items.title: The Thirst for Wholeness: Why Alcoholism and Addiction may be a "Broken Initiations"
items.author: Shannon Myers, MS, SEP
items.description: Addiction as a Spiritual Malady, Jung & The "Gift of Madness"and why Trauma Healing is the prerequisite for Intuition
items.content:
What if addiction isn’t a pathology, but a “psychospiritual malady”; a misguided attempt to touch the Divine?

We often view addiction - whether to substances, work, or perfectionism; as a disease of the will. But what if it is actually a misdirected spiritual event? A “Broken Initiation” where the seeker attempted to fly into the heights but lacked the Eldership to return safely?

We live in a culture drowning in information but starving for Wisdom. We have access to infinite data and “optimization,” but we lack the Initiated Elders who can hold the container when our reality expands beyond our nervous system’s capacity.

I sat down with Brian Maierhofer (Therapist, Writer, Actor, and fellow seeker) to map the invisible architecture of addiction, the necessity of initiation, and the somatic reality of spiritual awakening.

We connected over a shared truth: Traditional structures are failing us. Standard therapy often stays trapped in the cognitive mind. Executive coaching often ignores the wounded inner child. Both systems tend to bypass the ancestral, spiritual, and relational bodies that actually hold the keys to our wholeness.

In this conversation, we deconstruct the Myth of Icarus. We argue that his fall wasn’t a failure of hubris; it was a failure of Culture. It wasn’t that he flew too close to the sun; it was that the Elder (Daedalus) hadn’t built a container strong enough to catch him.

In this episode, we explore:

  • The Psychospiritual Malady: Viewing addiction not as a flaw, but through the Jungian lens of ancestral trauma and the “thirst for wholeness.”

  • Tuning the Instrument: Why you cannot develop clear Intuition or Psychic abilities until you heal your Trauma. (If your nervous system is stuck in survival, your signal is distorted).

  • The Physics of Co-Regulation: The resonance field of the nervous system and how to maintain energetic boundaries as a practitioner and human.

  • The Healing Vortex: Why true integration requires a return to play, making “bad art,” and expanding your somatic capacity to hold joy.

Watch the full conversation.

About the Guest:

Brian Maierhofer is a Therapist, Actor, and Writer. His upcoming book, The Gift of Madness, will explore how cultural dysfunction is being pathologized in individuals.

  • Follow Brian: https://substack.com/@brianmaierhofer

Work with Shannon in 2026

I have upgraded my practice infrastructure to better serve the collective. And have opened a limited number of new client spots for deep somatic healing, transpersonal healing, energy medicine + mediumship, mentorship, and strategic advisory.

Apply Here: https://theintegrativepractitioner.com/

The authenticity in me honors the authenticity arising in you.

-Shannon

items.description: A 25-year investigation into the medical-industrial complex and the "spiritual cosplay" of the wellness world; and the somatic strategy for living your values out loud.
items.content:
The Internal Compass: Why Living Your Values is a Radical Act of Rebellion

To live our values out loud is dharmic and a source of inner regulation. We can either silence our true north star and suffer or we can dream a world into being in which all are safe, belong, and their have human rights honored.

Somatics Science Spirit is a reader-supported publication. To receive new posts and support my work, consider becoming a free or paid subscriber.

As a complex Trauma survivor, I needed to start working very early. Many times folks are shocked when I tell them how I started working in dangerous situations for money paid under the table very, very early. Also due to childhood trauma, I had to take on a lot of responsibility early - more than most adults. Raising myself, my siblings, and my parents. Another piece to the puzzle as to why I am here teaching, is that I am neurodivergent and notice patterns.

Being neurodivent and surviving horrific conditions has lead me to being a rapid pattern detector of dysfunction. (I wrote more on that here.) In adulthood, I have sourced the wisdom from my trauma and it has lead me to being a systems change maker in my adulthood. With my systems thinking brain, I have been fortunate to help disrupt and change multiple systems. Of course with others aligned in the same values I embody.

This piece is a deep-dive on the 25-year investigation into systemic trauma and nonsense in the medical fields and wellness worlds. It is vulnerable, raw, and messy writing. And parts of me did not even want to publish it. Yet, I am choosing to embody courage today as courage always trumps complicity. Plus it will make my soul sing to cut through the noise of the status quo to bring you field notes of what is actually going on vs. citing off boring research.

Below is somewhat of an expose as I share real-life stories and examples of my 25+ year career attempting to fix the systems that harm. Some of the time it worked, other times I cried a lot and burnt out. Overall, I have no regrets as you can never go wrong living your values out loud. Our values being the closet thing to embodying the wisdom of our soul.

Of course, there was much disappointment in this quarter-of-a-century experiment as I noticed systemic patterns of collective dysfunction in nearly every system I encountered in the west. And because my values align with creating a world in which all are safe to exist and to make this world a better place: I have high hopes for humanity. I have seen a lot of changes and I have played a role in creating some of those changes.

So while I list out some of the absolute nonsense happening in the west - know that it comes from a place of hope. And from the acknowledgement that in every single sector and field, there are true bodhisottva’s working to fix broken systems. The more I awaken to our True Nature, the more I notice more truly enlightened beings working behind the scenes. In every sector, there are good humans serving heart-centered to enact change for all they serve.

It also needs to be stated that I recognize systemic patterns faster than most. This can upset folks who are not yet aware of systemic dysfunction. Later, many sheepishly will tell me that I was right and saw it early. Yet seeing something early should be something that is valued and not resisted. Because a dysfunctional pattern is a negative feedback loop. No matter if you notice it on day one or decades later. I just happen to be someone who notices it on day one and I do believe neurodivergent trauma survivors should not be discounted and instead cherished for the ways in which we notice.

There is a deep gift of noticing. And due to being what the world calls “neurodivergent” yet, I refer to being fully authentic, awaken, and soulful. However, not everyone’s soul hurts when they see others suffering like mine does apparently, so they don’t wake up with a fire in their belly to create changes in the world like I do. Yet I believe if folks were to truly heal into wholeness, they too would wake up and want to help resolve the suffering of humanity. So to me there is wounding with conformity with the status quo that creates suffering in the first place.

So if that is what “neurodivergent” means: I will proudly wear the label. Neurodivergent people and Trauma Survivors are like canaries in the coal mines - we warn society about patterns that can cause harm first after we are harmed due to our expanded nervous system and soul sensitivity. We should be listened to. Seeing things early could advert so much collective harm and suffering.

The Profit of Pain: Lessons from the Inside of the Pharmaceutical Sickness Machine

We need to talk about the elephant in the room. The USA healthcare system is broken. What is happening in the USA in terms of healthcare (and so much more) can’t truly be understood in other developed countries. Most other developed countries have universal healthcare and therefore cannot fathom the insanity that is the incentive structures of a for-profit healthcare system. In my 25+ year professional career, I have tried to change the system from the inside out in a variety of roles.

Many don’t know this but I was once a pharmaceutical sales representative. I was newly out of college with a very expensive business degree and my grandfather, one of the two safe adults in my life, had recently passed away from complications of diabetes. So I wanted to learn all I could about diabetes and became a diabetes pharmaceutical sales representative. I also had crushing student debt and it was either that or selling one of my organs.

If you have ever seen any TV shows about the pharmaceutical sales industry - they aren’t lying. It is gross and sad. There of course are good people in every industry so I don’t like making blanket statements. For me, this job was super rough and I learned a lot from the inside out.

Towards the end of my two-year stint as a “drug rep” carrying insulin samples and Cialis pills around - I found out the secrets to our healthcare system. P.S. This was way before social media and the internet being popular so cut me some slack on how long it took to connect the dots.

How did I uncover incentive nonsense? A doctor who was close to retiring was unhinged on a Friday afternoon. He didn’t have any patients and had some time on his hands. As he was weeks away from retiring, he finally felt like he could speak freely. So he called me into his office to show me how he made money off of writing prescriptions.

In his explanation, he essentially was told by the healthcare system he worked for that he needed to write a certain number of prescriptions. And from those prescriptions he made a bonus and received a kick-back. These weren’t small bonuses either - in the tens of thousands of dollars. Some of the kickbacks were made to him personally and most of them were made to his healthcare system - the clinic/hospital. None of this of course was his idea.

He then went on to me to tell me that certain diagnoses were more profitable then others. So his office was told by the healthcare system that he worked for to take certain patients with certain health conditions and not take others. COPD he told me was not profitable so he could not take new patients who had it.

So if someone called in a healthcare crisis who had COPD, he literally could not take care of them. If another potential patient wanted a better sex life and was looking for erectile dysfunction pills (which have a high margin of profit), he could take this new patient. And as someone who swore to not do harm as part of his Hippocratic Oath - you can imagine the ethical dilemma he was in and how much of a moral injury it was for him - as he truly loved people.

He also explained that when someone was very sick then they weren’t as profitable - so the answer was really to keep patients somewhat sick and to serve only patients who had profitable health conditions that could be prescribed certain pharmaceuticals.

I chatted with him for a couple hours that Friday afternoon. He spoke with tears in his eyes and rage in his voice. He did not become a Doctor to be a drug pusher he told me - he became a doctor to help people. And you know what? Many of the doctors who I came to know across my short drug rep career - said the same thing. So did the nurses and staff. I left his office that Friday and shortly afterwards.

Why the "Sickness Model" is Working Exactly as Designed

Later, after another stint in a role serving patients on the business side of things as a medical device sales representative who sold medical devices - I learned a lot about the insurance industry. It was in learning about medicaid reimbursement, medicare, and private insurance and the harms happening there - that I in part, went back to graduate school to become a counselor. I too wanted to help. And again, even in that field I was met with the sad reality that is healing in the America.

While I never diagnosed a soul or pathologized anyone as I was a non-traditional and non-clinical rehabilitation counselor (not a mental health therapist)…I had my heart broken in that field as well. While trying to help, I often felt helpless. There it was where I learned just how large the American system that kept people sick and suffering was. I learned it was designed to keep some people barely surviving and other people thriving.

It was in being a rehabilitate counselor that I would cycle between hope and hopelessness over and over again. Systemic barriers faced many who I served and it took super-human amounts of collaboration with human services colleagues across multiple organizations in order to sometimes pull off getting something funded for one mutual client of ours. We would work tirelessly in learning the various funding streams and ways in which we could hack the systems that harm.

All of us would hear horrific stories of human rights violation and suffering and many times we would have our hands tied behind our back. When something was funded by say a grant - we faced so much red tape and systemic barriers to prove that we deserved the funding.

Sadly, all the red tape meant a lot of times we spent the majority of the day writing reports to the system or systems funding the grant and not being able to truly help those suffering. It truly was maddening. And yet, we did pull off some amazing systemic changes.

It was in being a rehabilitation counselor that my faith was restored that there were so many other heart-aligned humans who truly wanted to reduce the suffering on the planet. Many of my beloved colleagues across various human services fields, therapy, and state and federal agencies that gave me hope.

Most of them were the most over-credentialed and underpaid professionals in America. They could have made four to five times more money per year in the business world and they chose to serve and be frustrated each and every day because they cared.

Yet we were set up to fail by a faulty system. By design. The system works to keep many people suffering and under-resourced. I truly believe many of the systems in America work for how they were designed. To keep some folks in positions of power and other folks dis-empowered.

In yet another Dark Night of the Soul, I started to get sick as my body was in constant stress so I chose myself and started to work for myself as an integrative healing practitioner, mentor, and consultant. The system change consulting work I did at my own business also was slow, painful, and grueling. Sick systems don’t change overnight and just like human nervous systems they get stuck in their own dysfunctional trauma loops.

So I continued to work with non-profits, the state and federal government, harm reduction education, and working at universities - just as a collaborator on the outside and not directly inside the system. For me, this felt better as I was less directly impacted by the chronic stress of having to work and be in a system constantly under tension.

Of course some good change happened and still there was frustration. Up until the past couple of years I saw real change start to ripple out. Today, many of those systems are being de-funded and critical lifesaving funds are no longer.

It honestly has broken my heart to have worked for so long and to have hoped for change and to see things still so broken. Yet I remain hopeful, as there are millions of good folks who believe in humanity and we creatively and collaboratively will figure it out. This I know for sure. We are who we have been waiting for.

The Wellness Illusion: When “Wellness” Becomes Another Performance

While I had high hopes for the wellness world when I became self-employed 15 years ago and hoped to make changes from the inside out - I also found a similar dysfunction there too. Just wearing a different hat.

Of course we sometimes think the grass will be greener on the other side, right? And the reality is that humans living in a dysfunctional society are going to do dysfunctional things no matter where they are.

And I really do believe the root cause of all of this is the overall dysfunction that is the western world that views the body and mind as something to dominate and medicate. The soul as something to outsource to a gate-keeping.

The implicit belief in an unwell culture is that healing needs to be performed and your ego needs to be inflated in order to belong. All of it of course, coming from un-examined conditioning and un-processed inter-generational trauma. Yet again, this is something that I likely see too early and maybe decades from now, society will come along.

While there are so many problems that exist in the traditional healthcare system - there are also a number of issues in alternative healing. I wanted to point out the wellness nonsense as so many are disenfranchised with the modern medical system. As well as, traditional healthcare seems to shut out anything holistic and of course people go seeking solutions.

And I get it. I once was completely disabled with 14 physical and mental health diagnoses and carried around a bag of medications. At one point, I was near death and could not walk and talk or speak. It was then that I had a metaphysical death and near death experience in which I learned my calling in life.

I am here doing that calling. Teaching and educating the masses. Values are to be lived and action taken for change to happen in our world. And I believe in a Trauma-Informed world in which the traditional medical model can be integrated with alternative and holistic health.

Once our society moves from rugged individualism and performing healing - we can hopefully realize we are interconnected and value individual and collective healing. As that is how our well ancestors healed from their physical and soul wounds.

So to be fair, I am going to point out some of the wellness noise going on. So that if in your seeking for wholeness you jump outside the medical model - that less harm happens. Below are just a couple examples of really poor Trauma work and neurodiversity nonsense being done under the guise of “healing” in the wellness world.

Let’s Start with Social Media

The algorithms work in such a way that they want you stay scrolling. They want people to stay in the comments and reply back and forth. Hopefully, emotionally so you stay on the platform. This is why engagement rates are tracked.

So we have well meaning practitioners teaching about trauma and then inviting their followers to share in the comments. Folks are sharing intimate details of their trauma history. There is no support or co-regulation beyond maybe the original poster writing a couple of sentences in a reply, or some emojis.

Yet those commenting have a nervous system that is time-traveling somatically and psychologically back to trauma-time. They may be reactivated. Of course the algorithm loves this because in their fight, flight, freeze, or dissociation - they stay on the platform and or buy things. This sadly is happening because trauma work and neurodiversity support is so inaccessible in America. So I get it. And I also want trauma survivors and neurodiverse folks to truly be supported.

What’s the solution? Actual community and safer spaces. Now this too is getting weird as folks are taking trauma survivors and neurodivergent humans off social media and onto WhatsApp, Telegram, and their own communities. While some good work is happening. Some cult-like stuff is occurring as well. Discernment is key.

From Screams to Biohacking: Decoding the Nonsense of Superficial Somatics

Okay, just for educational purposes: Often a trapped scream is often a trapped Fight response that needs to come out slowly, with titration, and pendulation in order to come into integration for healing to happen. When folks scream into the woods their fight parts may come out and may stay out. Anger may be unleashed without any containment or strategies to come down into integration.

The person may leave the retreat and hours or days later be very dysregulated, dissociated, and re-activated. Again, I get it. Facilitators want to help folks and nature is healing. But when we open up to trauma physiology without proper containment, it can get messy real quick. So if these types of retreats “don’t work for me” - it’s not you, Boo. It’s the lack of true trauma-informed support.

What’s the solution? Realizing that healing trauma is likely not going to happen in a weekend. What can happen though is connection with other humans who have also been through hard things. I really do wish these retreat facilitators would promote connection over trauma healing. Because connection is the piece of the work that is possible. What you can do is individually focus on connecting with others while you are there.

Masterminds Where Executives Over-Share About Their Trauma

The intention of many masterminds are right and again it is the container and support that is off. When folks do a lot of sharing in mastermind containers, there often is a lot of stress and trauma physiology present in the room. Being a business owner is by nature very stressful. And entrepreneurs are 500% more likely to have ADHD.

In my decades of working with folks with ADHD, I have never met one person with ADHD or thought they might have ADHD that wasn’t also traumatized because they did or may have ADHD. So let’s consider that most folks in a mastermind may have a trauma history.

Usually the share circle in a mastermind turns into over-sharing. Trauma neural pathways are opened and reactivated. Often folks connect and begin to trauma bond. Any way you shake it, there usually isn’t a trauma expert present that is doing deep and long-term trauma resolution work with the mastermind attendees.

There is often no time for the deep integration that needs to happen either. So these executives manager parts then come in to save the day and after the retreat make them overwork and hang on like hell to their success. While the rest of their lives may continue to be a mess. Again, no shade. I am reporting what is happening in our shared reality. Like I said, the intentions are good. The execution and containers may need to be updated.

What is the solution? What may be the best fit is to bring in a trauma expert to be with folks before, during, and afterwards for long-term integration and support. Another solution is for facilitators to get training in Trauma to be more Trauma-Informed. You don’t need to do anything about Trauma for attendees except recognize it and slow down to ground. Finally, participants can plan on scheduling afterwards with their Trauma practitioner, shaman, or supportive Trauma-Informed witness.

The Biohacking Trap: Why Wearables Can’t Replace Somatic Wisdom

Many in the wellness fields have lost the plot and for over a decade now I have witnessed influencers dominate their bodies online and then sell supplements, blood panels, trackers, you name it. I haven’t even shown a picture here and yet we both have an image in our mind of this archetype. As a trauma practitioner who is also trained in root causes of the physical nature, this has been brutal to witness.

Yes, so many biohacking things can work. But if you have unprocessed Trauma then you may as well dump your supplements down the drain. (I am not saying to literally do this - talk with your wellness practitioner.)

But we need to recognize that so many folks come to the biohacking movement from a place of chronic stress and unacknowledged trauma. The stories I could tell! When your trauma is processed, you are not usually using a lot of wearables unless biohacking is coming from a place of curiosity or your special interests. Instead, you can hear the signals in your body when Trauma is resolved. No Fitbit needed.

Trying to dominate the body in itself is a Trauma Response. Because when Trauma is healed: we are the body. Wholeness means the mind, body, and spirit are interconnected. So please, if you have spent a lot of money on supplements, panels, wearables, and biohacking; you may want to get curious about somatics, your limiting beliefs, and unprocessed chronic stress/Trauma.

Folks are desperate in America about their chronic dysregulation, lack of preventive care, and root-causes not being addressed due to a broken healthcare system and an emotionally immature and spiritually bankrupt society. So again, I get it. And what I am saying is that most biohackers absolutely are not trauma-informed. P.S. taking one online class doesn’t make someone trauma-informed. And there is a difference between being trauma-informed and being someone who can help you resolve trauma.

What’s the solution? Expanding out of all or nothing thinking. You can hack your health and also acknowledge your trauma. You can supplement and practice somatics. You can seek alternative solutions and also seek out trauma healing. Luckily, these days trauma healing can either be traditional or alternative. So align with your culture and values and do you, Boo.

And Don’t Get Me Started on Psychedelic Healing in the West

Holy hell. Holy f*cking hell. Of course very good things are happening. However, this is rare. I could write 75 more articles on this topic alone and still it wouldn’t scratch the absolute nonsense and lack of true trauma and shamanic training necessary.

Right now, we have therapists getting a certificate after one medicine ceremony and an online training. This training is lacking in what a soul may actually need. Plant medicines are conscious and you must truly earn the right to serve medicine.

Our indigenous ancestors get this more than the healthcare system yet they have been villianized for their ancestral training. What we can know is that you likely have not earned the rights to usher soul fragments of someone’s altered state of consciousness in a therapeutic setting from an online certificate.

Then there is the underground. And everything, everywhere, all at once is going on there. Of course there are very good things and wisdom tradition space holders that have been initiated and worked underground for decades and generations.

There are also un-integrated neo-shamans who have done a couple plant medicine ceremonies and are possessed with the Wounded Healer or Shaman archetype and don’t know it. The archetype isn’t integrated nor it their trauma. So all of that will be unconsciously projected onto your healing. Yikes, is that messy.

We also must acknowledge where many of these psychedelic medicines come from - animistic cultures that are collective and interconnected with the Spirit World. When a westerner enters that container, they have a western psyche. Not an animistic spirit that from birth understands the spirit world and the physical world are different sides to the Coin of Life. So many seeking psychedelic healing may end up with what I call “Ontological Shock” afterwards. The psyche/soul expanded too much, too fast, and too soon.

Preparation usually doesn’t happen in a trauma-informed way that the western mind needs. And then usually long-term psychedelic integration is bypassed entirely. At best, integration is misunderstood. Overall, these are done in a weekend or maybe a bit longer and then the person flies home and goes back to their job and life as if nothing happened. Talk about dissociation and parts not even landing! Much less integration happening.

I could go on and on but I won’t keep you. This is happening because humanity is in a spiritual crisis and is seeking spiritual solutions. I get it. I am taking issue with how it is being done and most of my consulting and teaching work has been around trauma-trained harm reduction for the USA, indigenous communities, and practitioners. Each situation of course is unique and overall, it is not going well. I remain hopeful and in service to creating more Trauma-Informed Care across the world.

What is the solution? For the facilitator it is doing your inner work and truly having enough of your own psychedelic egoless dis-identifying experiences so you stay humble. As well as getting non-traditional training such as eldership and shamanism. Along with of course, getting trauma-trained in multiple modalities.

Also, having at least one if not more difficult experiences yourself and working to integrate that over the course of a decade. Because you can’t truly integrate what you haven’t experienced. This is soul work and tropes used in traditional therapeutic training are not going to be enough for those with really difficult experiences, trauma histories, or having “ontological shock.”

For seekers, please use discernment. If something feels off, trust it. Understand that seeking a peak experience is often a Trauma-Response (I wrote about that here.) Urgency and rushing? Also Trauma-Responses. Get trauma support from someone who understand psychedelic integration and is also trauma-informed. This of course is the great paradox. Many wisdom traditions are not trauma-informed and many who are trauma-informed don’t understand shamanism, animism, and expanded states of consciousness. This bridge is slowly being built.

Systemic Humility: Building the Integrative Bridge Between Science and Spirit

TL;DR: In Summary the Traditional Healthcare is Broken and So is the Wellness World. And guess what? We are here to either improve these systems or create new ones. Humans are great at one thing: fixing problems.

However, it is problematic to point out problems and not come at it with some solutions. Even if the solutions are half-formed or misinformed to start out. So come at these issues with your half-formed solutions.

It is entirely ethical and moral to point out issues and provide solutions in your field or in areas you are seeking care. So many healthcare practitioners have been so traumatized by their fields that they fawn and appease and when someone calls out the systemic harm - they will defend the very system that is harming them too and those they are caring for. So I get why people often have a hard time with my direct approach to laying out issues and solutions.

Being The Change We Seek

Each of us at our core are not dis-empowered like these raggedy systems want us to think. We are empowered co-creators and we have thousands of small and big choices each day that we can make. Each of us can start to make changes in our lives and in the systems we are a part of by getting educated.

We can also open up our minds, get curious, and listen to the lived experiences of others. This can help us get outside of our own biases. Truly what heals one person has harmed another. So please understand that with about nine billion humans on the planet, it is going to take some time to come into collective Trauma-Informed Care.

The bridge from the east to the west is being built. Traditional and shamanic cultures are starting to talk to one another. So is the medical model and wellness worlds. It also is on every practitioner to really learn and humble themselves in what they think they know. Cultural competence starts with cultural humility. Trauma-Informed Care starts with education.

What I see as the major area to be improved is the fact that traditional healthcare world and human services fields have too much red tape, aren’t trauma-informed enough, and have not integrated holistic health. And then on the other hand the wellness world often does not have enough checks and balances, isn’t trauma-informed, and every health condition is just one biohack away from healing.

Overall, what all systems can do to get more with the times of where humanity is truly at is getting Trauma-Informed. You simply cannot have enough trauma-training. So take a trauma class once a year. Listen and read stories of lived experience. And stay curious.

How I resolved the disconnect of filling the gaps that folks fall through in the medical side of things and the nonsense that is happening on the other side in the wellness world - was to become an integrative practitioner. I embrace it all. And I remain critical of the gaps that people fall into so that I may do something to fix the systems in which we all are part, whether we like it or not.

My personal and professional solutions to our systemic dysfunction are: providing education, creating integrative service-offerings, writing to empower, and I have created an entire trauma-trained integrative modality. Because I not only professional investigated these fields over the last 25 years, I also was a complex trauma survivor who was neurodivergent and was harmed by the same systems. Since I have a choice to either complain or take action. I chose action. And I did what I could to create systemic solutions.

Pointing out issues within our respective fields is not a bad thing. It is natural to point out problems when you see harm happening. Awake humans do sit in silence witnessing other humans suffer. It goes against humanity and the soul.

Unfortunately, to question the status quo may come with negative consequences in an emotionally and spiritually immature society. I cannot say that I haven’t gotten harassed and misunderstood by pointing out issues and offering solutions.

So it may take a heavy dose of courage to stand up to systems that harm. Yet at the end of this day, this is soul work. To change systems that harm to make a more peaceful earth is what Bodhisattva’s do. It was what change-makers do. It is how awakened humans live and serve.

And it is what living your values out loud may mean. To fully be integrated and whole it means we take good care of ourselves and good care of our community. Making changes to systems that harm can create a lasting legacy that will be here long after our short time on Earth.

It does need to be pointed out that the most change I have seen in all of my career has been working one on one with individual clients and small groups. This is where I can use my knowledge of all of the ways I have trained and my knowledge of systems harm to help clients and groups resolve chronic stress, trauma, and live their values out loud too. And the last 15 years I have come to accept that all of the systemic nonsense is the result of the lack of a Trauma-Informed Society. And that is definitely something I can do something about.

So I aim to provide soul solutions for the very issues I have noticed. Generations from now my future family members who I have not met in the flesh and rather guide over in spirit, will benefit from my time here today. As will members of my shared human extended family.

That is worth being temporarily misunderstood by some people who have not had the same personal or professional experience as I have had. I can live with that. And my soul can dance across the cosmos knowing that my small self actually dared to do something with my precious time on this beautiful planet.

Heart-Centered Courageous Service Comes from The Authentic Self

Our practice this week is around courage. True courage comes from the Authentic Self - -which we can encounter in our soma/soul. Contrary to what you may have been conditioned to believe, courage does not come from fight parts that seek revenge on systems that harm. This is false courage and it comes from dirty pain that is unconsciously seeking to dominate or control the “other” in which it opposes.

True Courage comes from our clean core of our True Nature of the Self and it is patient, wise, and embodied. The True Self is heart-centered and comes at problems from a place of wisdom and full embodiment of the soul that does not seek quick superficial solutions. It seeks systemic and permanent change that ripples out. Including the courage to truly be our Authentic Self. As authenticity gives others permission to be themselves.

Unfortunately, courage coming from a place of wisdom and regulation often is not taught. Many advocates are coming from a place of unprocessed Trauma due to systems Trauma they have incurred. And I get it, as that was how I was taught to enact change. Yet as I healed, I saw another path. (To learn more about how trauma often showing up an advocates please read “No Bad Parts: Healing Trauma & Restoring Wholeness” by Dr. Richard C. Schwartz here.)

True change and heart-centered advocacy comes from a place of courage that is somatically heart-centered, regulated, and embodied. Trying to change someone or a system that does not want to be change, can be a boundary violation of another being. So to truly change systems, we must change ourselves first and in that change we will model the new world that we are co-creating with millions of other awakened souls.

Simply, to be courageous is to be whole. It is action without force. It is dharmic without dogma. And it is regulated. Know that it takes courage to bring goodness into a world that is often dysfunctional. And courage comes a place of increased somatic capacity. Which is why we will practice courage this week for our somatic practice.

The Practice: A Somatic Calibration for Increased Heart-Centered Courage

  • Come into noticing the room around you, 360 degrees, with softer eyes.

  • Breathe and blink.

  • Notice your feet/seat/body being support by the earth below you. Put one or both hands on your heart.

  • Think/feel/visualize the changes you are bringing to earth each day to make this planet more safe, beautiful, and a place where all belong. This can something as simple as being more present, creating art, or being kind. If you are working on a systems change project: think/feel/visualize its completion and who will benefit.

  • When you think/feel/visualize the changes you are making in your life or systems you are changing - next think/feel/visualize it all working out in the end. You were more present, you created more art, you were more kind. If you visualized systems change - imagine the change rippling out generations from now. In either case, this is legacy work. Feel into your body how it expands a little bit when you think/feel/visualize being more heart-centered and courageous a little bit more each day.

  • Yes, protective parts may show up and say negative things or make the body contract - that is natural. The good news is that both the Authentic Self and traumatized/conditioned parts can be present at the same time. You can kindly say back to that thought or part of your body contracting “thank you for keep me safe, I am practicing noticing what it feels like to feel/visualize a bit more courage leading to future change.” Then once again notice what it feels like to notice that what you are doing today can impact the future even if it is just 0.1% change.

  • Notice the shift from this short somatic practice. Notice the quality of your thinking, the sensation in your body, and the rhythm of your breath. Notice how things are a bit different for you since the start of this practice.

  • As you practice this week - notice yourself shifting. And if you want to, let us know how it is going in the comments.

  • If this practice felt difficult or “weird,” that is natural; especially for high-achievers used to “dominating” their body or advocates who have been conditioned that change has to be dysregulating. As always, somatic Trauma support can be transformative.

  • Know: You cannot get this practice wrong. Simply choosing courage over forcing change starts to re-calibrate your internal GPS and reminds your nervous system that you are becoming a little bit more whole.

    To move toward being more fully human, follow my writings, somatic practices, and love notes to humanity right here.

    The authenticity in me honors the authenticity arising in you,

    -Shannon

items.author: Shannon Myers, MS, SEP
items.description: Beyond the wellness noise: Why confusing stress with trauma stalls your recovery, and the somatic metrics for recalibrating your internal GPS toward wholeness.
items.content:
The Misinformation Trap: Why Confusing Stress with Trauma Stalls Your Growth

Social media is the Capital City of Trauma and Healing Misinformation. A lot of what is being “sold” as “Trauma Healing” on these platforms really only apply to Stress Responses. And Stress Responses are natural. Stress is part of life.

Of course stress can suck. Big time. But stress is not the same as Trauma. Stress without a Trauma history - stops after the threat. Stress is time limited.

Trauma on the other hand, continues to show up in your mind and body until as experiences of uncompleted self-protection responses. These uncompleted responses are the Trauma patterns that are continuing to show up as less-than-helpful patterns now. Trauma Responses keep going on and on until the uncompleted self-protection responses are completed. This is called “Trauma Integration.”

And we don’t want to villanize or pathologize Trauma Responses because: they kept you alive at one point. Yet Trauma Responses are ongoing. Trauma Responses can be stressful but they are entirely different than stress or stress responses.

The place where stress can cross over is with chronic stress. Our bodies are not meant to be in chronic stress. Unfortunately in a dysregulated society, chronic stress has gotten normalized. But chronic stress is entirely abnormal. Look to nature and the weather. A storm always passes. The sun comes out after the rain. This is natural. To chronically be in storm - is unnatural.

Our bodies can and do code chronic stress as trauma - coupling aspects of life as “dangerous” when chronic stress goes on too long. So that is the piece I will agree wellness influencers when it comes to Trauma. When stress is chronic it can impair (traumatize) the nervous system. And I still want to point out that many influences conflate trauma with stress. Stress and Trauma are NOT the same thing.

One really important thing I want to point out is with terminology of chronic stress vs. Trauma. Over the past couple of decades working with humans and teaching millions online - I have of noticed some trends. And one of those trends is that many folks will accept the term “chronic stress.”

However, many people will deny, minimize, or pathologize Trauma. Including healthcare practitioners. Want to know the biggest thing that holds folks back from healing? Most traumatized people will deny that trauma is the cause of their health and life difficulties. Or worse, their healthcare practitioner won’t understand Trauma.

Yes, I said it. Millions upon millions will never heal from Trauma because of the word “Trauma.” They will deny their Trauma or their healthcare practitioner will - and they will suffer. So I am not going to dance around words or nuance here. Your quality of life may depend on knowing the difference between stress and Trauma.

items.title: Organic Intelligence: Reclaiming the Rhythms of Your Nervous System
items.author: Shannon Myers, MS, SEP
items.description: Beyond the expansion myth: Why self-improvement fails without somatic integration, and the Oak Tree Protocol for returning to your Authentic Nature.
items.content:
Biological Rhythms: Nature’s 3-Phase Blueprint for Wholeness

One of the most common patterns of wholeness in nature is the process of coming into expansion, then contraction, and then integration. Nature does this over and over again, in cycles and rhythms. Many influencers and supposed “Trauma Experts” hyper-focus only on expansion. And while authenticity requires levels of expansion - it also requires the full integration cycle to happen. The full cycle includes expansion, contraction, AND integration.

And to complete a full healing cycle (integration) we need to have education, support, the conditions for the full cycle to occur, and inner somatic resources. In this article I will provide education and information for these conditions to occur.

We can also look to nature as our guide and teacher. The trees that grow in the Midwest region in America are great symbols of outer nature reflecting the potential of our inner nature.

Imagine an oak tree. It begins to bloom in the first season of the year: spring. In the next season, summer, it expands more and gets greener. In autumn, the leaves start to change color and contract; then begin to fall to the ground. This is the season where integration begins. And then in winter, the earth deepens her integration process and goes into rest and reflection. The final season, winter, is a period of bareness of the tree as it rests and reflects for the next full rhythm and cycle of growth in the spring. The death of the leaves becomes the fuel for the birth of a new season for the oak tree in the spring.

We are like oak trees. Our bodies and minds can expand, contract, and integrate just like a mighty oak - when given the right conditions and supports. When we begin to remember our True Nature, we can begin to embrace our inner nature. And from there we become more integrated and interconnected with our inner life force and the life all around us. Connecting with sun, water, and those around us to sustain our existence and full expression in the world. Humans are not so different than trees.

Oak trees and trees in general go into continuous cycles or rhythms, over and over again. That is what an expansion, contraction, and integration cycle is about. A cycle is part of a bigger pattern, a rhythm. Trees do not seek to complete one cycle but many. Humans who are healing can learn a lot from trees. For to change our Trauma Responses (unconscious body-based patterns called implicit memories) we can carefully and safely interrupt patterns.

Say what? Yes, I know. We don’t hear about this a lot. And because there is so very little somatic trauma-trained information out there. I have provided a practice of embodied pattern interruption - required to heal trauma and shift Trauma Responses into Healing Responses…at the end of this piece.

Reclaiming Regulation Rhythms: The Invisible Science of Human Interconnection

Trauma and stress cause us to chronically and unconsciously disconnect from our internal rhythms of being. Our sleep, our levels of human and spiritual connection, our health, our relationships, and our day-to-day experience of life is all about rhythms.

And we also carry healing wisdom in our bodies when we start to get curious how our bodies and rhythms can once again mirror nature. Just like the roots of trees “talk” to one another through complex root systems. So do human nervous systems. “Trauma Brain” will often cause us to to unconsciously be hyper-independent, super avoidant, or crave human connection while also fearing the vulnerability that may come with.

Complex Trauma causes the push-pull Trauma Response of desperately wanting to connect and fearing it at the same time. Which makes sense as Complex Trauma is rooted in thousands of relational ruptures that were not consistently repaired. So of course our nervous system, beliefs, and patterns had to creativity shapeshift to survive.

We share so many similarities with trees. Harming a tree’s roots weakens it significantly, reducing its ability to absorb water and nutrients, leading to branches dying, wilting, leafs scorching, and eventual decline, making it suffer, which endangers nearby or plants. It is wild how we are so alike.

Humans have the added component of having a social engagement system with mirror neurons. As well as personalities and stories. So when our roots are harmed like in childhood trauma, relational trauma, or systems trauma (racism, ableism, medical trauma, religious/spiritual trauma, educational/workplace trauma, betrayal trauma, political targeting, etc.) - of course our stories of ourselves, the world, and others shift to protection over connection.

This is why mind-set shifts are not enough. The mind is not the “root” - the body stores the root cause…and the solution. Slowly and safely (and often with practice and support) is how we begin returning our innate regulating rhythms. And the wildest part is that our body WANTS to come into more regulation and heal trauma. And our spirit craves authenticity. Our limiting beliefs and trauma is what is holding us back. And this is exactly what somatic practices can begin to address.

Somatic Sovereignty: Deconstructing Your Healing from the Domination Model

One of my favorite definitions of trauma is that Trauma is the chronic disruption of our internal rhythms. While it is my favorite it is not popular because most of the wellness world is built on the premise of domination and controlling the body. Domination and control is actually the opposite of coming into our innate internal rhythms. So I get why trying to heal trauma and being on social media right now is so hard.

Another difficult piece of the healing puzzle is that when you do engage with trauma healing information online most wellness influences aren’t actually trained it resolving trauma and only talk about expansion or contraction. So they do not understand the most important piece of the puzzle: integration. And they villianize contraction as if it isn’t the most natural thing in the world for a body to do when in a healing rhythm.

Right now, rest and regulation is sold and commercialized in a way to dominate and control the body. And I applaud the handful of trained somatic trauma practitioners that are cutting through the nonsense and noise and teaching true somatic healing. Our bodies are part of nature itself and are not to be dominated and extracted or controlled. They are to be listened to and allowed to go through natural expansion, contraction, and integration cycles.

Healing can be hard in the west because of eons of imperialism and dominating “the other.” Sadly, due to generation after generation of religiosity of denying the body - the body itself has been “othered.” And if you live the western world, we are conditioned to dissociate our bodies from nature. Most people think food comes from the store (not the land), do not get outside for hours a day (which our bodies naturally crave), and we are more isolated than we ever have been (and the human species is tribal/interconnected at our core.)

You might get laughed out of the office if you told your co-worker that our bodies are like trees. Because most of western world falsely believes we are “smarter” and “more intelligent” than trees. Rarely do folks remember that we get oxygen to breathe from trees and quite literally depend on them to live life. And this is where things get really messy for a lot of folks in their healing into wholeness process. Because to heal in an insane world, you may sound “out there” to those who have not gotten curious about their suffering.

So I get why healing in the west can be very hard and confusing. We have forgotten that to be human is to be part of nature. That we are nature itself. And if we forgotten this - of course we can get temporarily tricked into thinking we are some perpetual self-improvement project to be dominated and controlled.

Yet a tree doesn’t care. A tree is so intelligent that it goes through it’s own expansion, contraction, and integration cycle without any fanfare or story. A tree just trees. And like a tree, we humans can human. When the right conditions come together. When we come more into our internal rhythms and back to the true nature of our Authentic Selves. When we begin to question societal narratives that are causing suffering. When we are supported to be more of who we truly are. When we begin to metabolize trauma. And when we practice somatic practices with curiosity over self-judgment.

The coolest part about trees and humans is that we both contain healing impulses within us. It is why you are even here. You are at least a bit curious. Underneath trauma and social condition is your Authentic Self - waiting for Homecoming.

The whole reason that we humans are coded with Trauma Responses in the first place is to preserve our minds, bodies, and spirits. We are hardwired for preservation. And underneath that preservation is our true potential. Our bodies or soma and our nervous systems want to heal into wholeness. The GPS address however gets coded to go to the “wrong address” however with unprocessed Trauma and chronic stress.

Trauma and social conditioning causes our unconscious patterns to keep happening, until they are gently interrupted within our somatic capacity. And I honestly did not understand that fully until probably my tenth year of being an integrative trauma practitioner in my last couple years of Somatic Experiencing® training.

The 14-Diagnosis Turnaround: Moving Beyond the “Laundry List” of Diagnoses

Healing trauma is a lot. Real talk: for many of us being a human right now is a lot. IYKYK. And I understand how confusing navigating trauma healing can be especially when one person online says one thing and someone else says another. Then we have to add in the fact that when we have a trauma history or are neurodivergent our executive functioning is not well…functioning well.

So I get why wellness influencers don’t understand Trauma healing either and are teaching superficial stuff. But I want you to know that if someone is teaching only a partial truth or a misinformed truth - that does not mean healing isn’t for you. The fact is that a half truth is being recognized as BS by your body/mind/spirit. It’s not you, Boo.

And I would probably be more laid back about trauma healing too if I did not also live it and spend decades suffering with complex trauma and the disability of 14 different physical and mental health conditions running rampant as the echos of said trauma. Our body and mind can only scream in the ways we can pay attention: symptoms.

Like so many people online today, I went to probably 30 different doctors, therapists, and specialists with a laundry list of physical and mental health symptoms. I wanted answers. I got zero. So I get it. I wanted answers

What I ended up with were 14 different diagnoses. A bunch of medications that my body was epigenetically “allergic” too and compounded my suffering. Complex Trauma was never even suggested.

But my Authentic Self had a “HELL NO” deep with my body and a relentless case of curiosity that did not stop until I found solutions. Ultimately, I realized no one was coming to save me (a common child abuse and neglect pattern) and I saved my damn self in the end.

So dear readers, please know I didn’t heal from Complex Trauma until I got real with myself. This was brutal, painful, and I swam in the deep sea of a Dark Night of the Soul. My Authentic Self guided me through it and I dug into the research, trained, trained, and trained some more.

In the end, I healed differently than how we have been told to heal. I had to become the integrative practitioner I was so desperately seeking. And I did. She is now me.

So as an integrative trauma practitioner, when we are talking about expansion only or seeking only expansion… that is only part of the healing recipe that is trauma metabolization, stress reduction, and wholeness. When we expand too much, too fast, and too soon - our nervous system naturally contracts. This is supposed to happen as this is how our nervous systems naturally come into integration. Again, given the right conditions this can happen.

This is also why when folks go to retreats, do deep and intensive healing events, or do really long bio-hacking routines that are promoted online - why you may end up more dysregulated, with more intrusive thoughts, more anxious and more depressed, and with increased health symptoms. I was so jazzed to train in integrative mental health and then SO VERY disappointed to find out most of the integrative providers out there are not trauma-trained. So please remember, that too much, too fast, and too soon can RE-traumatize you. (And so can too little, not at all, or not enough.) Again, this is why trained trauma professional support that somatic is so very helpful.

Overall most of the time, with unprocessed trauma, there is not enough education, support, and guidance for the expansion, contraction, and integration cycles to happen. And the other piece where trauma healing may not be working is that there is no education on any of this - hence why I am here teaching.

And I know I am getting in the weeds here a bit - so what I want you to know: It is not your fault. What you can and are doing right now do right now is getting curious and learning. And you are in the right place. Like I said before I lived it. And I also trained in all the things: counseling, integrative medicine, trauma, business, coaching, shamanism, you name it… and noticed all of the gaps where people fall through and suffer even after seeking support. So I am integrating all of the myriad of things I have specialized and trained in to teach you over time, here.

Trauma-Training Decoded for You

Over and over again I will say the same thing: working with a skilled trained somatic trauma practitioner is life-changing. And I also know that not everyone can access trauma practitioners, hence why I write here.

To note: there are three levels of trauma training and most people (including many practitioners themselves) have no idea what each actually are.

  • Level one is being “Trauma-Aware”: this is someone who knows trauma is a thing. They can’t treat trauma but they know it exists. Some healthcare practitioners fall into this category and some coaches. Many folks who signal that they are “Trauma-Informed” are actually “Trauma Aware.” Why? They are aware of their Trauma. That does not mean they are aware of all Trauma. And it definitely does not mean they can treat Trauma. Finally, it does mean they have started their Trauma education journey and this is to be celebrated - because you have to start somewhere and there are some universal trauma patterns that they can education on.

  • Level two is “Trauma-Informed”: this person or practitioner may have a bit of training on trauma, can name the four main trauma-responses (Fight, Flight, Freeze, and Fawn), and may have some tips and tricks in their tool-belts. Most counselors fall into this category. Some influencers can fall into this category. This category can admittedly get very confusing. Most of the world only knows of this category so right now trauma-aware, trauma-informed, and trauma-trained practitioners are showing up online or on their websites as “Trauma-Informed.” So please ask someone questions if they are signaling they are trauma-informed. They may only be trauma-aware or they could actually be trauma-trained and help you heal trauma. A lot of things fall into this category including having some training on trauma.

  • Level three is “Trauma-Trained”: this person or practitioner is trained to help folks heal trauma in at least one modality. This is the rarest type of trauma specialist right now. Most trauma practitioners are trained in one main trauma modality. However, most trauma practitioners are not trained to help folks heal from complex Trauma. Being Trauma-Trained in complex Trauma requires being trained in multiple trauma healing modalities and relational strategies like attachment. Personally, I recommend that someone is also trained in neurodiversity if they claim to be Trauma-Trained. I fall into this category as I have trained in multiple trauma modalities, neurodiversity, have personal experience, and decades of professional experience.

    For example, because of my ultra-trained pattern mapping abilities and decades of working with clients and knowing own patterns - I track patterns that are often unconscious in most seekers, healers, and leaders. What I track in my sessions; is how folks can safely expand without doing too much, too fast, and too soon. So they don’t re-traumatize and dysregulate themselves further. In a couple months folks often remark that they metabolized more trauma and stress in a few weeks or months than they have in decades of talk therapy. And this how bad-ass our bodies are, when the conditions for change are supported by trauma-trained professionals. While I am trauma-trained, I often write online to the general public that I am “Trauma-Informed” - because most don’t understand what Trauma-Trained means…yet.

The Healthcare System is Broken, Not You

A broken healthcare system can make you feel like you are broken. You are not broken. Only 17% of healthcare practitioners are even trained in knowing about trauma (trauma-aware and trauma-informed), much less in helping you heal trauma (trauma-trained.) So it isn’t you.

Due to unprocessed trauma, your internal GPS is simply misfiring and going to the wrong location. That is what Trauma responses do. Trauma causes us to stay in survival mode unconsciously no matter what. And when something neutral or even good happens in our lives, it is mistakenly coded as a “threat.”

Why? Because neutral and goodness is not loaded into the GPS system of your body-mind as a pattern. Not yet at least. And that dear readers, is why we practice so much together when working one on one together. Healing into wholeness is a practice that not only is somatic, but also relational.

Neutral and good can also be tricky for those of us with complex trauma - such as childhood trauma or relational trauma. Because our nervous system remembers not to trust “good” things, because something bad is always going to follow. For those of us raised in chaos and dysfunction or living in a society that does not include your existence - of course the good stuff of life can be tricky.

And then we have these influencers online telling us what to do to heal. Somatic healing is really “hot” right not and it also is a hot mess. Folks take a three-month course online and think they are trauma experts. Or they read one book. Or they heal some of their Trauma and tell you to do the same things they did. But healing trauma is nuanced, non-linear, and messy.

And Complex Trauma? Good luck finding ONE thing that heals thousands and thousands of micro-traumas that often don’t come with clear memories and only emotional flashbacks, trauma-responses out of nowhere, and relationship difficulties.

So please do not get it twisted: Trauma expertise takes a lifetime. You can quote me on that too. Like I said, it took me ten years of trauma training to start to truly understand trauma healing. This was after having decades of Ph.D. in my own Complex Trauma and lived experience. Which was not enough to support all the ways in which trauma can manifest. Which are endless.

For the sake of your healing process, as much as you can, please do not judge yourself against whatever is happening on social media. Or against another person healing. Or even me. I will never be trained enough. No one working with trauma can be. We can however dedicate the rest of our lives as practitioners to staying humble, listening to those we serve, and being curious.

When healing and even being a healing practitioner, it is so important be kind and compassionate to ourselves as well. Trauma and social conditioning causes us to judge ourselves. Self-judgement and the judgment of others is sneaky trauma response. This keeps us safe, because then perfectionism comes in and so does the inner critic parts. And they try to keep us safe.

While of course causing a lot of suffering and trauma patterns that keep us in-authentic, stuck, and suffering. So I get why judgment parts may pop up. And it is our job in Trauma recovery, to get really curious and compassionate with ourselves.

So if you feel like it is taking you “too long” to heal or that a part of you thinks you “should be healed by now” or maybe another part judged you for “not being able to expand” like someone else - this is where noticing our patterns, curiosity, and self-compassion practices can help. As well as realistic trauma healing/integration like what I am hoping to convey in my writings.

items.title: The Soul Can't Be Selfied: Why Healing Trauma and Finding Wholeness Is So Uncomfortable
items.author: Shannon Myers, MS, SEP
items.description: An Authenticity Guide for High-Achieving Seekers
items.content:
Healing into wholeness is super uncomfortable. It will destroy illusions. We may have to grieve people who never realized their potential. We may even have to grieve timelines that we hoped would exist for ourselves that never realized. And the unspoken truth: We have to get real about our suffering and the roots of our suffering in order to heal into wholeness. This is why: Healing is So Uncomfortable That Most Folks Won’t Ever Do It.

Wholeness can and will change your life, health, and likely your relationship patterns. It doesn’t start out like that though. It starts out often as a mess, health crisis, mid-life crisis, existential crisis, burn-out, or deep loss of someone or something. Did I mention that it may look like a crisis? Yes, this is how our soul grabs our attention - wordlessly and often, drastically. The message unfortunately has to be loud because we were never taught how to truly listen to the wisdom of our bodies.
